clinical_study.brief_title: Preparing Caregivers for the Child Sexual Abuse Examination: Are Informational Leaflets Helpful?
clinical_study.official_title: Preparing Caregivers for the Child Sexual Abuse Examination: Are Informational Leaflets Helpful?

brief_summary.textblock: Children are typically inadequately prepared for the sexual abuse medical examination. Caregivers report lack of examination knowledge as a barrier to preparing their children. The purpose of this study was to determine if informational leaflets provided prior to the examination are helpful to caregivers in preparing their children.

primary_outcome.measure: To determine the helpfulness of informational leaflets in preparing caregivers for the child sex abuse examination
primary_outcome.description: [The study] undertook a prospective study of consecutive caregivers accompanying children for a scheduled sexual abuse medical examination. Prior to the appointment, caregivers were mailed information leaflets (in English and Spanish) about how to prepare their children for the exam. Caregivers completed pre and post exam surveys and the State-Trait Anxiety Inventory.

arm_group.description: Education of caregivers to counter lack of Preparedness for Children Undergoing Sexual Abuse Medical Examination

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- consecutive caregivers accompanying children for scheduled sexual abuse medical examination
Exclusion Criteria:
- Lack of consent
- Failure to complete study

clinical_study.keyword: Lack of Preparation for Abused Children during Medical Examination
